action.action-desc: Ms. Malliotakis (for herself, Ms. Meng, and Mr. Smith of New Jersey) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

form.official-title: To amend title 39, United States Code, to enhance the administrative subpoena authority of the United States Postal Service, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the USPS Subpoena Authority Act.

section.header: United States Postal Service administrative subpoena authority
section.text: Section 3016(a)(1) of title 39, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking subparagraph (A) and inserting the following:

subparagraph.text: In any investigation relating to a covered offense, the Postmaster General may issue in writing and cause to be served a subpoena requiring the production and testimony described in subparagraph (B). In this subparagraph, the term covered offense means a violation of—

clause.text: any section of chapter 83 of title 18 insofar as such violation involves the use of the mails;
any other provision of law enumerated in section 3001(a); or
the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 801 et seq.), insofar as such violation involves the use of the mails.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (C), a subpoena issued under subparagraph (A) may require—

clause.text: the production of any records (including books, papers, documents, and other tangible things that constitute or contain evidence) that the Postmaster General considers relevant or material to such investigation; and
testimony by the custodian of the things required to be produced concerning the production and authenticity of those things.

subparagraph.text: A subpoena issued in connection with an investigation under section 3005(a) shall not require testimony as set forth in subparagraph (B)(ii).

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (D), as redesignated by paragraph (1) of this section, by amending clause (iii) to read as follows:

clause.text: delegation of subpoena approval authority be limited to the Postal Service’s General Counsel, a Deputy General Counsel, or the Chief Postal Inspector.
